Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They notice someone in their circle going through difficulties and respond with care
Story:
I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at the last message from my boyfriend. We’d argued again—this time about money, and the words still stung. As his girlfriend, I knew I should try to resolve things, reach out, and smooth over the tension. That’s what a good partner does, right? But my heart felt heavy, tired from the same fight repeating itself all week.

At the same time, I’d just heard that Sarah, a friend from church, was struggling. She’d lost her job and was feeling alone. As a Christian, I felt a deep pull to reach out, to show her the love and kindness Jesus taught us. But I only had so much energy, and my mind was tangled in my own relationship problems. I wanted to be there for Sarah, but I also knew my boyfriend expected me to focus on us, to fix what was broken. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I sat there, torn, unsure which call to make first.
